lines.text: My minimum price for taking a stranded lady to a telephone is 400 dollars.
Will you take 375 in traveler's checks?
American Express?
Of course.
You've got a deal.
What is all this?
All this? About five to life in the States, a couple of centuries down here.
Oh, marijuana.
Oh, you smoke it?

[defensively]
I went to college.
What did you do, wake up this morning and say, "Today, I'm going to ruin a man's life"?
These were Italian.
Now they're practical.
Don't I know you?
No comprendo.
You are an American?

[changing to French accent to hide his identity]
Uh, odio, er... ah... americanos, uh... I spit on 'em, ptuh! I hate americanos, they're scumo! Scum!
Êtes-vous français?
There are schedules to be maintained, even in Colombia.
What's it gonna be, Angelina?
the filthiest, dirtiest, *dumbest* excuse for a man west of the Missouri River.
quick like the tongue of a snake, or slower than the molasses in January.

[voiceover]
But it was October.
I'll kill you, goddammit, if it's the Fourth of July! Where is it? Uhh. Get over there!

[voiceover]
I told him to get out, now that he had what he came for.
Not quite, angel.
[spits]
Take 'em off. Do it! Come on!
[Angelina kills Grogan by throwing a concealed knife]
Bastards had brothers, who seemed to ride forever.
Now I ain't cheap, but I can be had.
Why won't you take the elevator?
Oh, pumpkin, I never get into an elevator alone. You know... rapists.
[after reading Joan's new novel based on her adventure]
Joanie, you are now a WORLD-CLASS hopeless romantic.
No, hopeful. Hopeful romantic.
Hey Ira, the kid's here with the broad. They're taking her out to the boat.
Look at those snappers, will you!
We shoulda just rifled her room.
Ralph, how many times do I have to tell you, "It's not in the country"?

Well this kidnapping stuff makes me real nervous. It's a piss poor idea. It's nothing but trouble. Look, we've stolen enough of these antique trinkets to keep us living comfortably for the rest of our lives. Let's kiss-off this third-world toilet.
One last big one, trust me Ralph, trust me. Oh! Did you see that Ralph, that ugly, striped son-of-a-bitch down there!
Someone's gonna get killed, and you're farting around with prehistoric animals. Come on Ira, let's forget about this one. I've got a real bad feeling about it, real bad.
Will you stop worrying. Have I ever hurt you? I will never hurt you, I can't hurt you. We've got the same blood. We're not two people, we are one person! Would I hurt me?
[one of the alligators hisses]
Look at those snappers, Ralph!
This guy who is following you, he is very persistent!
Goddamn it, I knew I should've listened to my mother. I could've been a cosmetic surgeon, five hundred thou a year, up to my neck in tits and ass.
Wait a minute, he's after you. Who the hell are you?
Well, I'm a romance novelist.
You're what? What are you doing here?
I told you, my sister's life depends on me.
Ah, don't give me that shit. I thought you were donating a kidney or something.
One hell of a morning has turned into a bitch of a day!
You're the best time I've ever had.
I've never been anybody's best time.
What's the matter, are you paralyzed from the neck up, or are you hurt?
Of all the things you could say to me right now, "I lost her," Ralph, is gonna get the most teeth broken in your mouth.

Look, bullethead. If they're hiking through the jungle there's nothing I can do about it. I have a car. I am not Tarzan. I have been through every one-horse shithole for a two-hundred mile radius. You should have seen the river I had to traverse this morning. So don't give me any of your crap, you gutless wonder. You have been an embarrasment to our family ever since the day you were born! And let me tell you something else, Ira...
[he turns and sees Joan and Jack getting out of a car]
You are luckiest son of a bitch that ever walked the face of the earth! She's here!
She's there!
She's right here! She's walking towards the phone. She's with some guy. How do I know? She likes guys! So do you, maricon!
[last lines]
[Jack shows off his new crocodile skin boots made from the crocodile he has killed]
I like your boots.
Yup, that poor old yellow-tailed guy... developed a fatal case of indigestion. He died right in my arms.
I can't blame him. If I were to die there's nowhere on earth I'd rather be.
I couldn't stop thinking about you. I even read one of your books.
Then you know how they all end.
Yeah. Hi.
Hi.
[they kiss passionately]
Do they know who you are?
Oh, what, do you think I'm going up and introducing myself to every cop in the pueblo?
Crocodiles shed tears when they eat their prey. You have heard of these tears I am sure. But have you seen them?
You're a mondo dismo!
I'm... what am I? I'm what?
You're a man who takes money from stranded women!
How will you die, Joan Wilder? Slow, like... a snail? Or fast, like a shooting star?
Can we get there in your car?
Who told you I had a car?
The men in the village.
Pepe.
I had it in my hands, Ira. These hands that are going to break every bone in your body.
[Zolo points a gun at his face]
... later.
Excuse me, mister. Can you tell where can I get to a telephone?
No, lady. I don't have any idea. I'm sorry.
But it's very important that I get to one.
Well, we've all got our problems today. Don't we?
Can you tell me where the nearest town is?
English speaking? How about Miami?
Will there be another bus?
Another bus? This is it.
[looks around a deserted, dirt mountain road]
You've got rush hour.
I need to get to Cartagena.
Cartagena? Angel, you are hell and gone from Cartagena. Cartagena's over there on the coast.
But they told me this bus...
Who told you that? Who told you this bus was going to Cartagena?
That man...
That nice man who pulled a gun on you? What else did he tell you?
[first lines]

[a gunslinger breaks down the door of an old Western house and confronts the solitary young woman inside]
What's it gonna be, Angelina?

[narrating]
It was Grogan, the filthiest, dirtiest, dumbest excuse for a man west of the Missouri River.
quick like the tongue of a snake, or slower than the molasses in January.
[cocks the second barrel]

[narrating]
But it was October.
I'll kill ya, Goddammit, if it's the Fourth of July! Where is it?

[Jack and Joan find the stone in a cave]
Jesus Christ, we're in a lot of trouble.

[surprising them holding a gun]
Understatement of the year, asshole.

[to Joan]
Is there anybody who *isn't* following you?
Put the goods in the bag.
[Jack surrenders the stone]
Now move it, before Batman comes home.
I'm *stealing* this stone. I'm not trying to romance it out from under her.
Not only are we kidnappers, but I'm about to have a close encounter with a cattle prod!

[looking at a photo of his dream yacht whilst lying in bed with Joan]
Someday if I had the money, I'd take you... we'd sail away... around the world and back again. I promise you. I promise you we'll do that.
[they kiss and Joan holds Jack more tightly]
Why haven't you taken the map away from me?
What are you talking about?
I saw that tree today, the Devil's Fork, it's on the map. You know how close we are?
Yeah sure I do. What's that got to do with it?
I was thinking about something you said... about having more to bargain with.
Yeah. The best way to help your sister is to get that treasure and if you waltz into Cartagena you're holding all the cards.

[looks at the picture of the yacht, then back at Jack]
I'd love to see you on that boat. But Jack if we have to give it up... to save Elaine?
Then we give it up. I mean it's your sister. Hell yeah. Of course we give it up. That's the point. At least we've got the leverage to do it.

[looks at the picture of the yacht again, then back at Jack]
OK. OK. Let's got for it.
[they kiss]
What about the bridge?
That ain't a bridge. That's goddamned pre-Columbian art!
I understand you have a car. We would like to buy it or rent it, we need to get to a town.
What do you call this I'm living in, a pigsty?
Oh, no this is great...
Hit the road.
No, senor, see we...
Hit-the-road.
But we...

[Points a gun at him]
Vaya con Dios, gringo.

[Jack and Joan back off and turn around, to find that all of Juan's men have pulled guns on them too]
Okay, Joan Wilder, write us out of this one.
Joan Wilder... Joan Wilder? *The* Joan Wilder?
[Lowering gun, opening door and walking out]
You are Joan Wilder, the novelist?
Well, yes, I am.
I read your books! I read all your books!
[Turning to his men, in Spanish]
This is Joan Wilder, who writes the books I read to you on Saturdays!

[awestruck]
Juanita... Juanita, it's Juanita!
[all the men put away their guns and wave enthusiastically]

[picking up a magazine]
Dammit man, the Doobie Brothers broke up! Shit! When did that happen?
How long have you been down here?
Forever.

[Ducking bullets behind a boulder]
The cops? What do they want? I haven't done anything lately!

Wimp. Wimp. Loser. Loser. Major loser. Too angry. Too vague. Too desperate. God, too happy. Oh, look at this guy. Mr. Mondo Dismo. I actually used to date him. Total sleaze bucket. Wait a minute. Wait a minute. Hold everything. Get a load of this character. What about him?
No, he's - he's just not...
Who? Jessie?
Maybe it's silly, but, I know there is somebody out there for me.

[On the phone]
All right, cousin, as usual, you got us in some serious sh*t here. First of all, the stupid dame got on the wrong bus. Now, I'm stuck in some kind of Spic-o military compound. They're mobilizing for Iwo Jima here.
Do they know who you are?
Oh, oh, do you think I'm going up an introducing myself to every cop in the pueblo?
Lady, you are a jinx!
I think I'm going to throw another key on the fire.
No, please, I'm getting dizzy.
What do you want? Seriously? I'd really like to know.

Came down here in a coffee boat, about a year and a half ago. Right. Christ, what job that was. But, I couldn't get over that ocean, though, you know. Yeah. I love the ocean. You know you just got to get out there - all by yourself - nobody else around. It's beautiful. So, that's what I want. Try to get enough money together to buy a boat and sail around the world.
So, you're just gonna sail away? All by yourself?
Yeah.
Sounds lonely, Jack T. Colton. - - Well, what does the T stand for?
Trustworthy.
Friendly, aren't they.
Drug runners. Just try to look mean.
What I would really like - would be a phone.
No. No. No. No. No phones. No phones. I hate phones. I don't have a phone. But, have a drink! Let's hang out!
Well, wait a minute, now. Going for the stone was my idea.
Ah, that's what all the good con artists want you to think. He made you think you needed it, you sap!
Which way to do we go?
Follow that stone!
